msContents.summary: 'The Rate manuscript', a compilation of Middle English verse - romances, exempla, comic tales, and didactic and devotional texts, many known only from this manuscript - copied by 'Rate' in the late 15th or early 16th century. The contents of the entire manuscript are edited by George Shuffelton, Codex Ashmole 61: A Compilation of Popular Middle English Verse (Kalamazoo, MI, 2008).
msContents.textLang: Middle English (dialect of north-east Leicestershire: eLALME LP 71) with a little Latin (fol. 21v)

msItem.title: Life of Saint Eustace
msItem.note: Lines 1–32 only, breaking off; torn leaf formerly affixed to fol. i(a). At the bottom of the leaf, in a different ink, is a fragmentary table of contents for the volume listing texts by incipit or title.

msItem.title: Life of Saint Eustace
msItem.incipit:
Al þat be on godes lore
Lytell mykyll lesse & more
Lystyns to me A stound
Of a knyght of hethenes
msItem.explicit:
And þer with outen end to wonne
God þat grace vs send

msItem.author: John Lydgate
msItem.title: Rammeshorne
msItem.incipit:
Thus Ryght wysnes do now procede
And sytyht lyke A gay emprece
Law hath lorn All maner of mede
Ant settyht vp treuth als hyȝe as god is
msItem.explicit:
Thus be we gouerned for soth as I gesse
Conueyed by lyn

msItem.title: How the Wyse Man Tawght His Son
msItem.incipit:
Lordynges & ȝe wyll here
How a wyse man tauȝht hys sone
Take god hede to þis matere
And fynd to lerne it yff ȝe cane
msItem.explicit:
And Ihesu bryng vs to his blysse
The chyld þat was in bedlem borne
msItem.note: Omits stanzas 6–11, first half of 13, and 14.

msItem.title: The Good Wife Taught Her Daughter
msItem.rubric: þe Goode Wyfe tauȝt hyr Douȝter
msItem.incipit:
Lyst & lythe A lytell space
I schall ȝou telle A praty cace
How þe gode wyfe tauȝht hyr douȝter
To mend hyr lyfe & make her better
msItem.explicit:
And bring vs to thy hyȝhe blysse
That neuer mor fro vs schall mysse

msItem.title: Sir Isumbras
msItem.incipit:
Hende in halle & ȝe schall here
of elders þat be fforn vs were
There lyues how þat dyde lede
I schall ȝow telle A wonder case
msItem.explicit:
And to heuen yer saules wente
When yi dede were

msItem.title: The Ten Commandments
msItem.incipit:
Herkyns serys þat standes A bowte
I wyll ȝow tell with gode entente
How ȝe to god schuld kne & lowte
Iff ȝe wyll kepe his commandment
msItem.explicit:
ȝiff þat they wyll fro syn them kepe
They schall be bryȝter þan þe sone
msItem.note: The Speculum Christiani version of the Ten Commandments occuring separately, with a unique stanza prefixed and three others appended.

msItem.author: John Lydgate
msItem.title: Stans puer ad mensam
msItem.incipit:
Ihesus cryste þat dyed vpon A tree
To bye mans saule þat ons was for lorn
Helpe þem wele in All þer degree
That doth euer ryght be hynd & beforn
msItem.explicit:
Take A candell in þi hond Anon & hold hym lyght
To he haue drownkyn what he wyll styll by hym þu byde

msItem.title: Dame Courtesy’s moral instructions
msItem.incipit:
Whosoever wyll thryve or thé
Muste vertus lerne and curtas be.
msItem.explicit:
God gyff them grace vertuos to be,
For than thei may both thryff and thé.

msItem.title: Latin epigram
msItem.quote:
Tempore felici, multi numerantur amici.
Cum fortuna perit, nullus amicus erit.

msItem.author: Sir John Fortescue (attrib.)
msItem.title: Twelve points for purchasers of land to look to
msItem.incipit:
Who so wyll be were in purchasyng
Consider þe poyntes þat be þer Inne
msItem.explicit:
And in x ȝere if þou wyse be
Thou shall a geyn þi money se

msItem.title: Latin epigram
msItem.quote: O Asside, Asside, dico te Romanos superare.

msItem.title: Latin epigram
msItem.quote:
Tres infelices in mundo dicimus esse
Infelix qui pauca sapit spernitque doceri
Infelix qui multa sapit spernitque docere
Infelix qui sancta docet si uiuat inique

msItem.title: Evening prayer
msItem.incipit:
Ihesus Lord well of All godnes
ffor thi grete pety I þe pray
ffor gyffe me All my wykidnes
Where with I haue grenyd þe to dey
msItem.explicit:
My body my soule I þe be ken
In nomine patris & filij & spiritus sancti

msItem.title: Morning prayer
msItem.incipit:
Ihesu lord blyssed þu be
ffor All þat nyght þu hast me kepe
ffrom þe fend & his poste
Wheþer I wake or þat I slepe
msItem.explicit:
ffrom All euyll sprytes þu me defend
And in my desesys to be my socoure

msItem.title: The Ten Commandments
msItem.note: Repetition of the first two stanzas of The Ten Commandments (fols. 16v–17r).

msItem.title: Orison to the Virgin Mary
msItem.incipit:
Mary moder wele þu be
Mary moder thinke on me
Moder and mayd was neuer none
In þis werld bot þu A lone
msItem.explicit:
That I may fynd it so be
Amen Amen for charyte
msItem.note: Occurs as part of Speculum Christiani and separately.

msItem.title: Debate of the Carpenter’s Tools
msItem.incipit:
The shype Ax seyd vnto þe wryght
Mete & drynke I schall ye plyght
Clen hose & clene schone
Gete þem wer as euer þou kane
msItem.explicit:
And bryng vs All vn to his blysse
That neuer fro vs schall mysse

msItem.title: Prayer at the Levation
msItem.incipit:
Welcom lord in forme of bred
In þe is both lyffe & ded
Ihesu is þi name
Thow Arte god in trinyte
msItem.explicit:
Heyll fader son & holy goste
Welcom in forme off brede

msItem.title: The Knight who forgave the Slayer of his Father
msItem.incipit:
By twyx two knyghtes be ȝond þe se
ffell a gret conteke to be
By twyx þem fell syche wroth & wo
That þe one weyted þe oþer to slo
msItem.explicit:
And þat it myght so be
Prey we all for charite

msItem.title: The Earl of Toulous
msItem.incipit:
Ihesu cryst in trinite
O god And persons thre
Gyff vs wele to spede
And gyff vs grace so to do
msItem.explicit:
Graunte vs All þi blyssing
Amen for charyte

msItem.title: Lybaeus Desconus
msItem.incipit:
Ihesu cryst owre sauyowre
And his moder þat swete flowre
They sped them in þi nede
That lystyns of A conquerour
msItem.explicit:
ȝe schull haue þe blyssing
Of Ihesu cryst All so

msItem.title: Romance of Sir Corneus
msItem.incipit:
All þat wyll of solas lere
Herkyns now & ȝe schall here
And ȝe kane vnderstond
Off a bowrd I wyll ȝou schew
msItem.explicit:
God gyff vs grace þat we may go
To heuyn amen amen

msItem.title: A miracle of the Virgin Mary: The Knight and his jealous wife
msItem.incipit:
Lorgynges curtase & hene
lystyns how þis tale schall ende
That I wyll ȝow seyne
And if ge wyll with gode wyll here
msItem.explicit:
Dorste no lenger A byde
Bot fled A wey full sore

msItem.title: Tale of an incestuous daughter
msItem.incipit:
That I schall neuer with þe dele
At bede at bord mete ne mele
My synne I haue for sake
A sche seyd þu wyked man
msItem.explicit:
Vn to Ioy Ioy þat we may wende
Lord for þi holy grace

msItem.title: Sir Cleges
msItem.incipit:
Lystyns lordynges & ȝe schall here
Off Ansystores þat be fore vs were
Bothe herdy & wyght
In tyme of vter & þendragon
msItem.explicit:
There saulys went to heuen clere
There is Ioy eith outen ende

msItem.title: The Founding of the Feasts of All Saints and All Souls
msItem.incipit:
Ihesu cryst of myȝhtes most
fader & sone & holy gost
Be At ouer be gynneng
And saue mans kynd fro spyllyng
msItem.explicit:
Wyth gode hert þat it so be
Sey we Amen for charyte

msItem.title: The King and His Four Daughters
msItem.incipit:
Ihesu cryst heuyn kynge
Be at my be gynninge
There is no man þat may ȝelpe
Bot he hath nede of godes helpe
msItem.explicit:
All contake leyd schall be
My wyll it is I schall saue ye
msItem.note: Translation of Robert Grosseteste, Chateau d’Amour.

msItem.title: Ypotis
msItem.incipit:
All þat wyll of wysdom lere
lystyns to me & ȝe schall lere
Of a tale of holy wryte
Seynt Iohn þe Apostyll wytnes ite
msItem.explicit:
Here endys þe talkyng
God grante vs all hye blyssyng

msItem.title: The Northern Passion
msItem.incipit:
Lystyns lordynges I wyll ȝow tell
Off mekyll pete I may ȝou spell
Off Ihesu þat vs All hath wrouȝt
And seth oure saules dere hath bouȝt
msItem.explicit:
And þat it myȝht so be
Amen Amen for charyte

msItem.title: Short Charter of Christ
msItem.incipit:
Wyteh wele all that ben here
And after schall be leve and dere
msItem.explicit:
In wytnes of that yche thynge
Myn awne sele therto I hynge

msItem.title: A lament of the Virgin Mary
msItem.incipit:
In A chyrch As I gan knelle
Thys endres dey for to here messe
I saw A syȝht me lykyd welle
I schall ȝou tell how þat it was
msItem.explicit:
Thynke on hys passyoun And hys blys
ffor thy son dyȝed my dere sone dere

msItem.author: John Lydgate
msItem.title: Dietary
msItem.incipit:
ffor helth of body couer fro cold þi hede
Ete non raw mete take gode hede þer to
Drynke holsom drynke fede þe on lyȝht brede
And with Apytyte ryse fro þi mete also
msItem.explicit:
Off mayster Antony ne of master hew
To all deferent it is dyatary

msItem.author: Richard Maidstone
msItem.title: Seven Penitential Psalms
msItem.incipit:
Lord in thyn Anger vp take me nouȝt
And in thy wreth blame þu not me
ffor certys synne hath me throuȝt souȝt
That I wer laste nere helpe of the
msItem.explicit:
In heuen kyndom to haue sesyn
All myȝhty god in persons three

msItem.title: Stimulus conscientie minor
msItem.incipit:
All myȝhty god in trinite
ffader & sone & holy goste
That is one god & persones thre
O stedfast god of myȝtes moste
msItem.explicit:
And grante hym lyue þat lastes aye
In heuen where joy is euer mour new
msItem.colophon: Nunc finem feci da michi quod merui

msItem.title: The Stations of Jerusalem
msItem.incipit:
God that schupe both heuen & helle
To þe lord I make my mone
And gyne me grace þe sothe to telle
Of þe pylgryme Age þat I haue gone
msItem.explicit:
Off þe lord to haue in mynd
ffor to be hold þi blyssyd face

msItem.title: Lamentacio peccatoris
msItem.incipit:
All crysten men þat walke by me
Be hold & se þe dulfull syȝht
It helpys not to calle ne cry
ffor I am a dampned a dollfole wyȝht
msItem.explicit:
Farewele I here an horn blow
I may no lenger byde with thee

msItem.title: The Adulterous Falmouth Squire
msItem.incipit:
Man fro myscheff thou thee amend
And to my talkyng thou take god hede
msItem.explicit:
ffro dedly syne god þe defende
And vnto blys þi saull schall fare

msItem.title: The story of the Resurrection
msItem.incipit:
When Ihesu was in graue leyd
The bysschop vnto An oþer seyd
The best rede þat we can done
To sir pylate we wyll gone
msItem.explicit:
God send hem grace to take þe wey
To þe blysse with out endyng

msItem.title: Life of Saint Margaret
msItem.incipit:
Old & ȝong þat here be
lystyns A whyle vnto me
What I schall ȝou sey
How it be fell vpon a dey
msItem.explicit:
pray we All þat may so be
Amen Amen for charyte

msItem.title: The Wounds of Christ as Remedies against the Deadly Sins
msItem.incipit:
Wyth scherp thornys that be kene
My hede was crounyd as ye may sen
msItem.explicit:
That this lesson wyll rede
And therwith ther saulys fede

msItem.title: Sir Orfeo
msItem.incipit:
Mery tyme is in Aperelle
That mekyll schewys of manys wylle
In feldys & medewys flowys spryng
In grouys & wodes foules syng
msItem.explicit:
And þat it may so be
Prey we All for charyte

msItem.title: Vanity
msItem.incipit:
O vanyte off vanites & All is vanite
Lo how þis werld is turnyd vp & downe
Now wele now wo now tranquilyte
Now werre now pese & now rebilyoun
msItem.explicit:
Bot labour in pouerte to þe tyme þat we dyȝe
ȝit is not labour not bot vanyt

msItem.title: The Kyng and the Hermit
msItem.incipit:
Ihesu þat is heuyn kyng
Iff þem All god endyng
If it be þi wyll
And ȝif þem parte of heuen game
msItem.explicit:
The blast of þat horn made hem glad
To þe towne þan gan þi fare

supportDesc.support: Paper, in 'holster book' format with horizontal folds on every leaf, evidently present before writing (e.g. fol. 34). Three watermarks: (A) fols. 19-57, quires 3-5, ring with crown and cross above, cf. Briquet 694 (Palermo, 1479); (B), fols. 58-84, quires 6-8, hand with 6-leaved flower or star above, cf. Briquet 11159 (Genoa, 1483) and 11165 (Perpignan, 1505); (C) unicorn, closest to Briquet 10116 (used 1488). Fols. ii(b), 1-18, 92-104 are unwatermarked. Beta-radiographs are available in the Bodleian Library.
supportDesc.extent:
iii (unfoliated modern paper, added 1986) + i (19th/20th cent. paper, fol. i) + i (laid paper, fol. ii(a)) + 1 (original paper leaf, fol. ii(b), formerly glued to fol. ii(a)) + i (unfoliated modern paper, added 1986) + 162 + i (17th cent. laid paper) + iii (unfoliated modern paper, added 1986) leaves
c. 417-8 c. 138-141
supportDesc.foliation: 19th-century (still in use today), i, ii(a), ii(b), 1-30a, 30b-162.
Earlier foliation (probably 16th-century, possibly scribal), omitting the first quire (present fols. 1-8), then runnign 1-91, 91bis, 92-150, 160-2.
supportDesc.collation: 1(8), 2(10), 3(12), 4(16), 5(12), 6(10-2, wants 9 and 10, no loss of text), 7(12), 8(14), 9(14-1, 8 cancelled after fol. 91(a)), 10(16)-11(16), 12(14), 13(16-5, 12-16 wanting; fols. 151-161); as reconstructed by Bruce Barker-Benfield in 1986. The first quire was not included in the early foliation and may have been a late addition to the manuscript, but its contents are included in Rate's table on fol. ii(b). Catchwords, possibly scribal.

layoutDesc.layout: 1 col., c. 44-60 lines; written space typically c. 350 70 .

handDesc.handNote: Anglicana with secretary /a/, by one scribe, signing as 'Rate' or 'Rathe'; possibly to be identified with one of the man named William Ratt or Rot(te) active in Leicester in the late fifteenth or early sixteenth centuries. Scribal drawings of fish and flowers throughout the manuscript have been associated with a device of Leicester's Corpus Christi guild (Blanchfield).

decoDesc.decoNote: No significant decoration; no rubrication; yellow wash applied to some capitals
For drawings of fish and flowers see above, Hands.

binding.p: Previous late 17th century binding kept with the manuscript: dark brown calf with gilt fillets and simple blind-roll tooling on the outside edges; two claps with the arms of Ashmole. Repaired and rebacked in the 19th and/or 20th centuries.

history.origin:
15th century, late, or 16th century, early (watermarks)
England (perhaps Leicester) (see above, Hands)
history.provenance: fol. 161v, Item to me from M. Austin of Hook norte[?] on Thursday 2 couple of Rabbitts the Thursday following 2 couple more Thursday the 15 of August 2 couple more, 16th or 17th century, i.e. Hook Norton in Oxfordshire. Fol. 106v, “Delivered d dame Elizabeth [sic].”
Bequeathed by him to the Ashmolean Museum.
history.acquisition: Transferred to the Bodleian Library in 1860.

recordHist.source: Description by Andrew Dunning and Matthew Holford (December 2021, rev. May 2022), based in part on the Digital Index of Middle English Verse; George Shuffelton, Codex Ashmole 61: A Compilation of Popular Middle English Verse (Kalamazoo, MI, 2008); Gisela Guddat-Figge, Catalogue of Manuscripts Containing Middle English Romances (Munich, 1976); and Lynne Sandra Blanchfield, ‘The Romances in MS Ashmole 61: An Idiosyncratic Scribe’, in Romance in Medieval England, ed. by Maldwyn Mills, Jennifer Fellows, and Carol Meale (Cambridge, 1991), 65–87. Collation and watermarks after descriptions made by Bruce Barker-Benfield at the manuscript's rebinding in 1986. Previously described in the Quarto Catalogue (W. H. Black, A descriptive, analytical, and critical catalogue of the manuscripts bequeathed unto the University of Oxford by Elias Ashmole Esq...., Quarto Catalogues X, 1845). Quarto Catalogue, col. 106 Quarto Catalogue, cols. 107–8 Quarto Catalogue, cols. 109–10 Summary Catalogue, vol. 2, part 2, p. 1123

revisionDesc.change: James Cummings Up-converted the markup using https://github.com/jamescummings/Bodleian-msDesc-ODD/blob/master/convertTolkien2Bodley.xsl
